title: What if China gave Manchukuo back to Japan? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s Dongbei not Manchukuo (or Manchuria) Today, that region is called Northeast China or Dongbei (literally East North) in Mandarin Chinese. Manchukuo is the Japanese name of the ILLEGITIMATE PUPPET STATE in Dongbei. China would never give Dongbei back to Japan since it is not Japan’s to be given back in the first place. It was sovereign territory of China that was illegally invaded and occupied by the Japanese. And China sees its sovereignty over the region as absolute. China giving the Japanese Dongbei is about as likely as them giving Qingdao back to the Germans, Hong Kong back to the British or the Japanese giving China Kyushu. In a hypothetical world….Japan would not want it anyway But in a hypothetical world if China did decide to give Dongbei to Japan they likely would not even want it. Back in the 1930s when Dongbei was conquered by the Japanese it was an almost untouched land of resources of all kinds. They were needed for Japan to become a fully modernised industrial nation given how resource poor Japan is. And Japan back then was still a mostly traditional country - the architecture, clothing, cuisine, technology and overall way of life for most Japanese had more in common with its past than the lifestyle of the elites in Tokyo. Today, Japan is a fully modernised industrial nation. It’s people live a life completely different from its traditional one. Even the ones in rural villages have paved roads, modern houses and cars. Thanks to global trade it has access to all the natural, energy and agricultural resources it needs. Its managed to become a confident, technologically advanced, futuristic nation through global trade. And Dongbei now is the opposite - it’s natural resources are almost depleted and as a result the region is now an economically backwards, poor rust belt region. It suffers from high unemployment, stagnation, population outflow, low birth rates, high debt levels, pollution. Japan’s occupation of Dongbei was brutal…..Chinese would hate it The legacy of Japanese imperialism is negative in China and especially in Dongbei. It was on the outskirts of one of Dongbei’s largest cities, Harbin, that Unit 731 was built. They performed biological experiments and used Chinese people as targets or materials for weapons experiments. They infected them intentionally with lethal diseases, used them in bomb experiments as live dummies. Most cruelly for those infected with diseases, so the Japanese could observe how the virus infected a body and the immune system responded they would vivisect (cut open) Chinese people, some of them children and pregnant women: ALIVE, FULLY AWAKE and with NO ANAESTHETIC. The Unit 731 Museum in Harbin gives a detailed look into the full scale of the atrocities the Japanese committed. And so low they thought of the Chinese that they referred to their human test subjects as Maruta (meaning tree log in Japanese). The Japanese also infected surrounding villages with viruses too for the same reason. Chinese would protest both inside and outside of Dongbei. Why is the Chinese government giving sacred Chinese territory …… to JAPAN!. The Chinese government would be seen as not defending Chinese sovereignty and its people. If the Chinese government was crazy enough to even consider it they would back away immediately following mass protests. This would threaten the Communist Party of China’s legitimacy and rule over China. So why would China and Japan want a region with only negatives So why would Japan want another region that’s resource depleted, suffering from many of the economic and demographic issues lots of regions in Japan are experiencing, that would saddle them with even more debt and filled with a hostile population almost equal in size to Japan’s population. And why would China want to give away a region that could result in mass protests, weakened legitimacy and even a threat to their right to rule. Non existent hypothetical But all this is ultimately just hypothesising and it can only go so far because in reality the situation is almost completely implausible. China would never give it away. And Japan doesn't want it.
